key_behaviors: Uses Claude almost every day for baby‑related questions, recipe creation, and translation tasks
Relies on Claude‑built app (by husband) to track running data
Employs AI tools (Clotter, TrackGPT) for quick information look‑ups and synthesis
Double‑checks AI‑generated outputs before using them in personal or professional deliverables
Prefers to invoke AI only when needed, keeping it out of the primary workflow UI
pain_points: AI interfaces can clutter the UI and get in the way of primary tasks
Lack of visible prompts/questions makes the interaction feel static and “talking to the void”
Interview with an AI felt “annoying” because it was long, not dynamic, and didn’t show the questions
No summarization or echo‑back of user input, leading to uncertainty whether the AI is listening
trust_factors: Higher trust when AI provides suggestions but the user makes the final decision
Lower trust when AI acts on the user’s behalf without explicit control
Need for the AI to be transparent (show questions, summarize input) to demonstrate it is listening
Reliance on personal verification (e.g., double‑checking translations) to protect reputation
desires: A streamlined, on‑demand AI that does not intrude on existing UI
Ability to summon AI only for specific tasks without it “getting in the way”
Real‑time summarization or echo of user statements so the user can confirm accuracy
Clear visual display of the AI’s questions/prompts during a conversation

verbatim_quotes.quote: I use Claude to ask specific questions or baby related questions and cooking, I think it's really helpful when you have more specific things.
verbatim_quotes.topic: General AI usage for personal tasks

verbatim_quotes.quote: Think I probably use it almost every day. It's helpful for I had to create a recipe for someone that a friend that just had a baby ... My husband built a app through Claude to track his runs.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Frequency and variety of Claude usage

verbatim_quotes.quote: I can't think of times that it didn't [meet my expectations].
Sometimes AI can get in the way of things. Like, just clutter the UI of something a little bit too much.
I think like, when there's specific tasks that I'm trying to execute, just not getting in my way of those things and being something that I can go to when I need it rather than ...

So I think it's maybe less trusting when it's, um, doing things on my behalf, like, I don't know. Without, like, my ... that's why I'm so comfortable with Claude because it doesn't do anything for me. It's more on my terms of when I engage with it.
I guess I don't mind having AI's input. For any kind of decision as long as I'm the one making the decision.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Trust factor: final decision remains with user

verbatim_quotes.quote: I was asking AI to translate a Spanish recipe for me. And it gave me a translation, but I still kinda looked it over and double checked that it was making sense.
Because, ultimately, I'm the person delivering you know, the recipe or the final report, and I have to sign off on it. ... So I'm not going to be, risking my own reputation in that way.
It starts to get a little long and not as dynamic as talking to a person ... seeing the question would help ... rather than just the dot blinking at me.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Pain point: lack of visible prompts

verbatim_quotes.quote: Showing me the questions when you're talk giving me a question ... maybe even, like, summarizing what I'm saying back to me ... making it a little bit more dynamic.
You would show me that it's actually listening to what I'm saying and give me an opportunity to correct it?

unique_insights: The participant treats AI as an extensible tool that must stay under their direct control, even for low‑stakes tasks like recipe translation. They explicitly link UI clutter to reduced willingness to engage, and they request real‑time visual feedback (displayed questions and summarization) as a core trust mechanism—suggesting that perceived attentiveness, not just output quality, drives trust.
